Excuse me if I weigh in on this subject with a few thoughts:

1) I agree with the sentiment that testing behaviors is the desired
methodology for writing tests rather than explcitily testing methods
themselves. You eventually wind up testing methods, but since the purpose is
to find bugs, and find them as early as possible, behavioral testing should
be the focus. This may seem to conflict with how some people do or view TDD,
and it does require viewing the Code Under Test in a more abstract manner,
but that is generally a "good thing".

Behavioral testing is good because it helps the code writer/tester keep the
"big picture" in mind rather than getting lost in the code, and because
while the code itself may go through several iterations, behavior changes
less often - this results in more flexible tests, test code that needs to
change less often, and it keeps a high degree of separation between the code
executing the tests and the CUT. Closely bound code is a bad thing, whether
it is in testing code or the CUT, or between the two.

2) Behavioral testing results in higher reuse of the test code. It may also
result in higher reuse of the CUT since it may help reusable patterns
emerge.

3) Being both a developer and a SQA engineer, I often write unit tests for
other people's code. TDD is relatively new and unused by much of the
industry, unit-testing in general having been in use much longer. I usually
test at a more abstract level. I don't use the terms "white-box" and
"black-box" for testing as much as unit-testing, module testing, sub-system
and system testing, integration and acceptance testing.

Almost anything at any level can be thought of as a black box, and to
initially test a unit I don't really need to have a white-box knowledge
level of the code - just the interface, method signatures and preferably the
JavaDocs. Indeed, I prefer not to look at the internal code of a unit at
first - I find I am more productive, more generalized and less biased in how
I test if I treat the unit as a black box first, then drill down into the
actual code later. This way my testing code tends to be less tied to the
CUT; e.g., I don't know or at this point care whether the CUT uses a Vector
or an Array to store items.

4) To make sure that non-visable methods are properly tested, code coverage
tools should be used in lieu of explicitly writing tests for these
non-visible methods or code. This results in making explicitly sure that all
code is actually tested (more so than writing tests that access private
methods directly) - which is the purpose, it is more productive, and it may
point out unused code or logic errors missed by just assuming that because
the test passed the code has been completely tested. Testing code is only as
good the measured results. Pass/fails are one type of result, code coverage
metrics are another - the latter more qualitative than the former - and they
should be used together.

Granted the above observations and opinions come more from my viewpoint as a
tester of other people's code, but I believe they are valid. I have noticed
that much of the test code written during TDD tends to be skimpy in coverage
(both code and test conditions), and because it is usually highly bound to
the CUT it is often not maintained well when the code is changed. Few
developers write good tests, even fewer can test their own code well. As
such, while I encourage TDD since it is productive in its own right - I also
mandate that more extensive unit tests be written from a more abstract view
outside of the code. This usually entails a person, other than the original
coder, writing more extensive unit tests. Almost invariably, these tests are
best maintained separate from the original code.

FWIW,
Lauren
